Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Curriculum Driven Gamification of Space Exploration
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project connects society through communal exploration of the universe. This product will be commercially useful to enhance scientific and technological understanding of astronomy in the K-12 classroom, the college astronomy laboratory, and in the hands of internet gamers around the globe, adding value to the partnerships between academia, industry, and the public. Due to the internationalism of both this project and the greater astronomy community, this project will develop a diverse and globally active camaraderie among players that fosters collaboration and socialization across geographic and economic borders in pursuit of space education.

The proposed project addresses the need for relatable astronomy education by gamifying space exploration through robotic telescope use. The project aims to advance scientific knowledge of astronomy through the use of gamified, curated astronomy curricula that bring authentic remote observing practices into the classroom and any personal platform with internet access. The project will take users through a series of quests to explore the regions of the night sky, and the objects within, defined from the eighty-eight constellations recognized by the International Astronomical Union. Explorer badges will be awarded on a "gravity point" system of successful observing missions, encouraging the practice of real astronomical observing, data handling and image processing practices, and comprehensive content research. The methods to successful implementation will include research of game design, establishing partners to support distribution of the learning materials into classrooms, and web/mobile application development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Phase I of the NSF SBIR program, Slooh created a platform to enable beginners of all ages to learn how to explore the night sky in an interactive way. The design is based on a gamified experience of a series of Quests that teach students astronomy via the use of online optical telescopes. The Quests take students on a self-directed exploration of the Slooh 1000, a catalog of the most interesting visible objects in the night sky, by choice of either a structured curriculum or a tailored, personal experience. In the process, students learn how to use telescopes just as professional astronomers do, mimicking the same phenomenon-based practices of astronomy research.

Customer research conducted during this program solidified the proposed market need that astronomy covers a very small percentage of the science requirement in K-12 curricula, and that is largely in part to the difficulty in teaching astronomy in a hands-on manner. Telescopes require nighttime in-person viewing, significant expertise of operation, and are expensive. They are also subject to distress of poor local weather. Slooh aspires to integrate hands-on astronomy into the curriculum by providing a virtual laboratory for educators to outsource the teaching of astronomy to.

The major R&D component that Slooh set out to accomplish in Phase I was the development of a software tool that enables staff astronomers and educators to create the guiding steps of each Quest without the need for any software programming expertise. The successful completion of this advanced administrative system allows for a growing base of Quests that increase in difficulty level as Slooh users increase in expertise.

In addition, Slooh created complementary educational tools and materials to aid in the self-guided learning process as students progress through their Quests. The new Slooh platform hosts supporting Guides that include detailed information about the Slooh 1000 objects and key astronomical concepts, contextually embedded within the experiences along the way. Slooh also supports new explorers through a variety of live lecture series that explore topics in greater detail with audio and video components, and with a new Ask An Astronomer Anything feature which promotes direct conversational engagement with professional astronomers and builds a public-facing knowledge base of answers to frequently asked questions. The new Slooh platform, launching in Q4 of 2018, will help students learn about space by giving them the tools to explore it for themselves.
